keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by President Trump in 2021 after participating in the Capitol riot, was arrested in October 2025 for allegedly threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan made a text-based threat to kill Jeffries, leading to a felony charge of making a terroristic threat under federal law.
Moynihan was previously sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and received a full pardon as part of a broader group of over 1,500 Capitol riot defendants.

The arrest comes amid a broader national trend of rising threats to lawmakers, with Capitol Police reporting a dramatic increase in threat assessments, reaching around 14,000 cases by the end of 2025.

Jeffries criticized the blanket pardon, stating that many pardoned individuals have committed additional violent crimes, and law enforcement is now forced to spend significant time protecting communities from such individuals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a 34-year-old man pardoned by President Trump in 2021 after participating in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, has been arrested on a felony charge of making a terroristic threat to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. The threat was allegedly communicated via text, and Moynihan was arraigned in Clinton, New York, with a bail amount ranging from $10,000 to $80,000. Moynihan previously served 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release. His arrest comes amid a growing national concern about the safety of lawmakers, as the Capitol Police report a dramatic increase in threat assessments—up to 14,000 cases by the end of 2025. Critics, including Jeffries, argue that the blanket pardon of over 1,500 Capitol riot defendants—including individuals with prior convictions for crimes like domestic violence and sexual abuse—has allowed violent individuals to re-enter society and commit new offenses.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
